summary.seg: This manuscript, probably copied in the 13th century, contains theological works of Maximos the Confessor, mainly canonical letters. The author was abbot of a monastery in Chrysopolis, near Constantinople, who was exiled and mutilated for his opposition to the doctrine of Monothelitism, introduced by the Emperor Heraclius I (610-641).

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [a-b], I + 1-3, 3(a), 4-19, 19(a), 20-43, 45, 47-75, 75(a), 76-139, 141-142, 144-150, 150(a), 150(b), 151-168 + [c], in Arabic numerals, in black ink, recto, upper right.
supportDesc.collation: The manuscript consists of 24 quires: 18+1 26-1+2 (1 missing) 38-2+2 (7 and 8 missing) 48-4+4 (1, 3, 6 and 8 missing) 58 68-1 (7 missing) 78-2 (1 and 8 missing) 8eight (all gone) 98-3+2 (2, 7 and 8 missing) 108-2 (1 and 8 missing) 118+1 (1 inserted) 12-188 198-2+1 (3 and 6 missing) 208-2 (1 and 8 missing) 214 222 234-1 (1 cancelled) 2410

binding.p: 18th-century binding with grey paper covering over couched-laminate boards, with a white parchment spine and plain pastedowns. The classmark appears on the spine on patches.

physDesc.accMat: A loose slip of paper is inserted between ff. 87 and 88, bearing notes on the content of a manuscript in Latin and Greek.

history.acquisition: Donated by Thomas's son, the antiquary Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744 , in 1738.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College: a descriptive catalogue

analytic.title: La deuzième lettre à Thomas de Saint Maxime le Confesseur

msItem.title: Contents list to an Oxford manuscrip of Maximos the Confessor
msItem.note: f. i recto is blank apart from various notes

support.material: ff. i, 3(a), 9-10, 17, 22, 24, 27, 29, 47, 54-59, 61, 66, 139 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Pot ( 79 35 ) in the centre of the folio, comparable but not identical to Heawood 3611, 3623-3624, Churchill 466. These examples are dated to c. 1623-1642.

layoutDesc.layout: f. i verso A single column of 41 lines. 210 135

handNote.p: ff. 3(a) recto-3(a) verso, 9r-10v, 17r-17v, 24r-24v, 27r-27v, 29r-29v, 47r-47v, 54r-59v, 61r-61v, 66r-66v, 139r-139v were copied by Patrick Young (Hand B), in a western European mixed minuscule script resembling early printing, in brown ink.

physDesc.additions: On f. i recto are a series of notes in Latin regarding the use of the works of Maximos by John the Scot and Photios. Slips of paper with other notes on the content are pasted to this folio.

history.origin: These folios were added to replace losses to the original manuscript by Patrick Young in the first half of the 17th century.

msItem.author: Maximos the Confessor
msItem.title: Epistulae XLV
msItem.note: ff. 1r-4r Letter 8 (PG 91, coll 440-445); ff. 4r-8r Letter 6 (PG 91, coll. 424-433); ff. 8r-19v Letter 13 (PG 91, coll. 509-533); ff. 19v-23v Letter 14 (PG 91, coll. 533-544); ff. 24r-64r Letter 12 (PG 91, coll. 460-509)
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Μαξίμου μονάχου ἐπιστολὴ πρὸς Σωφρόνιον μονάζοντα, τὸ ἐπίκλην εὐκρατὰν
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Ὁ κατὰ σάρκα πόθος· χρόνω μαραίνεσθαι πέφυκεν
msItem.explicit: f. 64r καὶ ἀειπαρθένου Μαρίας, καὶ πάντων τῶν ἁγίων ἀμήν

msItem.author: Maximos the Confessor
msItem.title: Epistula ad Iohannem cubicularium
msItem.rubric: f. 64r-64v Ἴσον ἐπιστολῆς Μαξίμου μονάζοντος πρὸς Ἰωάννην κουβικουλάριον+ Μαξίμου μονάζοντος πρὸς Ἰωάννην
msItem.incipit: f. 64v Ὁ πάντα πρὶν γενέσεως ἐπιστάμενος Θεὸς· πᾶσιν ὡς οἴδε συμφερόντως μετασοφίας
msItem.explicit: f. 65v Δι' ὃ, παρακαλῶ τοὺς εὐλογημένους ὑμᾶς δεχομένους αὐτὸν

msItem.author: Maximos the Confessor
msItem.title: Epistulae XLV
msItem.note: ff. 66r-89r Letter 1 (PG 91, coll. 364-392); ff. 89v-117r Letter 15 (PG 91, coll. 544-576)
msItem.rubric: f. 66r Λόγος παραινετικὸς πρὸς τὸν δοῦλον τοῦ Θεοῦ Γεώργιον γενόμενον ἔπαρχον Αφρικῆς παρὰ Μαξίμου
msItem.incipit: f. 66r Ουδεὶς οὕτω τῶν φωτὸς, ὡς οἶμαι, καθ' οἷον δήποτε τρόπον ἐστερημένων
msItem.explicit: f. 117r ὁ μόνος σὺν Πατρὶ καὶ Ἁγίωι Πνεύματι δεδοξασμένος εἰς τοῦς αιῶνας, ἀμήν

msItem.author: Maximos the Confessor
msItem.title: Ambiguorum liber
msItem.incipit: f. 117r Τῶ ἡγιασμένῳ δούλου τοῦ Θεοῦ πατρὶ πνευματικῷ καὶ διδασκάλω κυρίω Θωμᾶ
msItem.explicit: f. 139v τοὺς τὸν ἄνω κόσμον πληρώσοντας· αὐτῶ δόξα· μεγαλωσύνη· κράτος· σὺν τῶ Πατρὶ καὶ τῶ Ἁγίω Πνεύματι, εἰς τοὺς αἰώνας, ἀμήν

msItem.author: Maximos the Confessor
msItem.title: Epistula secunda ad Thomam
msItem.rubric: f. 141r Τοῦ αὐτοῦ πρὸς τὸν αὐτὸν
msItem.incipit: f. 141r Ὑπόστασιν μὲν σοφίας, τὴν ἀρετὴν· οὐσίαν δὲ φασὶν ἀρετῆς
msItem.explicit: f. 150r καὶ μὴδὲν ἡγεῖσθαι πίστεως συγκεχυμένης ἐπιδοζώτερον· ὧν τὸ ἀπερρίφθαι Χριστοῦ

msItem.author: Maximos the Confessor
msItem.title: Epistulae XLV
msItem.rubric: f. 150r Κυρίω ἀββὰ Ἰωάννη, πρεσβυτέρω καὶ ἠγουμένω· Μάξιμος μοναχός
msItem.incipit: f. 150r Πιστεύω καθῶς παρέλαβον καὶ ἐδιδάχθην, ὅτι ὁ Θεὸς ἀγάπη ἐστίν
msItem.explicit: f. 150(a) verso οἱ τὴν ἀλήθειας τῆς φιλαυτίας προτιμὰν μελετήσαντες

msItem.author: John of Damascus
msItem.title: Dialectica (recensio brevior)
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning, with lacunas: begins ed. Kotter, section 5
msItem.incipit: f. 150(b) recto ται εἰς δύο· εἰς τὴν κοινὸς διαφορὰν, καὶ εἰς τὴν ἰδίως διαφορὰν
msItem.explicit: f. 168v τὸ ἀνύπαρκτον δηλοὶ ποτὲ δὲ τὸ συμβεβηκός

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 24 quires, of which one is a quinion, two are ternia, two are binia, one is a single bifolio and the rest are quaternia.

list.item: Quire 18+1 (ff. 1-8: 2nd leaf and 7th leaf are singletons; leaf added after f. 3).
Quire 26-1+2 (ff. 9-15: 1st leaf missing before f. 11; two paper leaves added before f. 11).
Quire 38-2+2 (ff. 16-21: 7th and 8th leaves missing after f. 21; one paper leaf added after f. 16)

Quire 48-4+4 (ff. 22-29: 1st leaf missing before f. 22; 3rd leaf missing after f. 23; 6th leaf missing after f. 26; 8th leaf missing after f. 28; four paper leaves added, one each in the same locations).
Quire 78-2 (ff. 47-54: 1st and 8th leaves missing, f. 46 and after f. 53; two paper leaves added, one each in the same locations)
Quire 88 (ff. 55-59: quire of perhaps eight leaves, all gone, and replaced by five added paper leaves)

Quire 98-3+2 (ff. 60-66: 2nd leaf missing after f. 60, 7th and 8th leaves missing after f. 65; two paper leaves added, one each in the same locations. The stub conjoint with the 1st leaf, f. 60, is now bound between ff. 54 and 55)
Quire 198-2+1 (ff. 137-145: 3rd leaf missing after f. 138; paper leaf added in this location; 6th leaf, f. 143, missing)
Quire 208-2 (ff. 146-150(a): 1st leaf cancelled before f. 146, 8th leaf missing after f. 150(a))

collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, in black ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto in the middle of the lower margin. Many have been lost to cropping or the loss of folios. They survive on Quires 5-6, 9, 12, 14-19 (εʹ-ϛʹ, θʹ, ιβʹ, ιδʹ-ιθʹ). The number 3 (γʹ) appears on Quire 22.

supportDesc.condition: In average condition. Numerous leaves lost throughout the volume. Those that remain have suffered from damp and water-staining, especially around the edges, and the leaves have become stiff and cockled. The stitching has deteriorated and some leaves are beginning to come loose. Patches of dirt or discolouration on some leaves (for instance, ff. 38r, 39r, 45v, 48r). A large repair patch in the upper margin and upper part of the text block on f. 167, not affecting the text.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 1r-3v, 4r-8v, 11r-16v, 18r-21v A single column of 25-27 lines. 157-170 105
Pricking survives in all three margins, but some has been lost to cropping. Ruled in hardpoint, system Leroy 1, type Leroy 20C1s. The relationship of the text to the lines varies, and they are sometimes ignored.

ff. 23r-23v, 25r-26v, 28r-28v, 30r-45v, 48r-53v, 60r-60v, 62r-65v, 67r-138v, 141r-168v A single column of 20 lines. 155 100
Pricking survives in all three margins, but some has been lost to cropping. Ruled in hardpoint, system Leroy 1, type Leroy 20C1s. The relationship of the text to the lines varies, and they are sometimes ignored.

handNote.p: ff. 1r-3v, 4r-8v, 11r-16v, 18r-21v, 23r-23v, 25r-26v, 28r-28v, 30r-45v, 48r-53v, 60r-60v, 62r-65v, 67r-138v, 141r-168v were copied by Hand A, in upright mixed minuscule script similar to Perlschrift, in brown ink, with minimal variation in letter size and occasional flourishing of tails into the margin. There are deletions by expunctuation

Syllabic abbreviations appear only at the end of lines and and superscript word endings are not in use. Breathings are both angular and round and mute iota is adscript or absent, or occasionally subscript. There is occasional decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra. The circumflex appears over breathings, and is someimes but not always enlarged when it does. The double grave accent and marginal quotation marks are in use. Horizontal strokes appear above proper names. The hyphen is used to merge words.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower and middle commas, question mark and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink, in Alexandrine majuscule script in red ink, or in Alexandrine majuscule script in brown ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: The beginning of the text on f. 1r is preceded by a rectangular headpiece, outlined in brown ink with red infill, the text on f. 89v by a pyle in the same style, and that on f. 117r by a pyle outlined in red and brown ink with red infill. Simpler, slender horizontal headpieces outlined in brown ink with red infill precede the beginning of other texts (e.g. ff. 8r, 23v).
Some texts begin with ornamented initials outlined in brown ink with red paint infill (e.g. ff. 20r, 64v, 105r).
Other texts being with smaller, simple initials in red ink (e.g. ff. 100v, 117r). The beginnings of sections are also marked by simple minor initials in red ink

additions.p: There are occasional brief marginal notes by various hands, in Greek (e.g. ff. 1r, 146r), including a note on f. 12v mentioning the names Andreas Phlebaris Phlebaris, Andreas and Andreas Mengoulas Mengoulas, Andreas , and in Latin (e.g. f. 131r).
There are a number of marginal notes in Latin and Greek by Patrick Young (e.g. ff. 42r, 52r, 117r).

history.origin: The original body of the manuscript was probably copied in the first half of the 13th century, as suggested by the style of script. The general appearance of the script and particular features such as the continued use of angular breathings and adscript mute iota would tend to indicate production in the 12th century, but mute iota occasionally also appears in its fully subscript form (e.g. f. 19r, lines 8, 10, f. 25v, line 3), which does not generally occur before the 13th century, and these marks do not appear to be later additions.
